blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
It is not in vain that people say that the moment you put your finger in the sea you are universally connected with the entire world.
This is a true thesis on the sea and people worth for everyone, especially for those who live and feel the sea, deeply rooted inside them. It is so with our sea, too, the blessed indented shoreline which wrinkles its lovely face, making it thus an even prettier old man. So much could be said and written about it, but in this book that tells a story on postcards we can only in the end present those most special ones that connect Dalmatia with the rest of the Croatian Adriatic.

A mini chapter in front of you represents its particularities. Numerous inhabitants of its depths with rich fauna, as well as its luminous guides – lighthouses. While the series of postcards with the Adriatic fish, made in 1898 by the Lošinj photographer Benedikt Lergetporer, is absolutely unique and surely among the oldest photographs with this topic, the postcards with the lighthouse motifs done in commercial circulations, on the other hand, are also less surprising. From today’s perspective it is truly amazing that Lergetporer came up with the idea to arrange with the local fishermen to record for eternity their everyday catches and use these photographs as templates for making photo-postcards. Their circulation is very questionable as well as the question if there is any similar postcard from that opus. The eight postcards shown with the motifs of the Adriatic fish were found in Vienna, where they have spent over a hundred years in an album, an integral part of the Lergetporer’s opus which was made up of as much as 96 postcards of the island of Lošinj, taken in the period from 1897 till 1905. The entire album was bought in 2014, at the auction in Salzburg, by the collector Franko Neretich who keeps collecting patiently and with nostalgia in the far-away New York everything that is dear to his heart, regarding his native island and the Adriatic. Revealing these postcards can be called sensational, because from that time, and also later there just aren’t any postcards with similar motifs. They are far more than a mere piece of paper, a memory of all the fishermen and their sleepless nights, horny hands, worn out from pulling out the nets, rowing and everyday fight to survive. It is also a memory of the wealth of one of the clearest seas in the world.

Unfortunately, we don’t have the opportunity to see the postcard showing the sardine – the feeder of the poor, even though the Lošinj archipelago was teeming with this blue fish at that time. Throughout the Adriatic at the beginning of the 20th century there were factories for processing sardines, which employed thousands of workers. Only in Komiža, on the island of Vis, there were six of them. Today all of these factories are empty, in the places which slowly die out, and they are decaying under salt and rust. The salt of that same sea which used to give away, and today it is roaring: Oh, yes, you humble servants, you will remember the days when you were blessed with abundance, and already now you are crying for the damage and neglect which you caused by your disrespect for me!
Just as all that bustle in the sardine factories and the worker passion are long gone, so did that same sardine disappear at the beginning of the new millennium for several years from the depths of the Adriatic sea, and that fairly frightened all those who live of the sea and with the sea. As expected, the question arose whether that was the beginning of the end… or not yet, but only a reminder of how many spices are threatened and might die out. With nostalgia, I remembered the stories of the Lastovo fishermen how, back in time, at the period of lobsters spawning, one could have watched from the coast tenths of their tentacles peeping from the shallows of the crystal clear sea, which is today considered to be just wild imagination. The habitats of this unique crab are almost destroyed today, because of the modern ways of fishing and often uncontrolled overfishing. But it is not only lobster that is endangered, but also other heroes from these postcards: John Dory, shrimps, red mullet… Is it possible that Lergetporer, like Nostradamus, foresaw that someday instead of going to the fish market and enjoying the Mediterranean folklore which it offers, we would carry these fish only in our memories, so he decided to give them main roles in his deltiology play. I believe not, the motive was strictly creative, and let us hope that the human consciousness will be triggered in time and give us strength to face the challenges of the modern ages and preserve the seas and their fauna.
Therefore, let the main protagonists of these eight postcards shown not remain just mere memories, but our everyday life like the lighthouses are, which represent a special addition to time when one was sailing on the Adriatic without the contemporary navigation devices, and the ships were prowled by many rocks, invisible to the naked eye.
The light that is reflected from these stone titans saved lives, opened paths towards Italy in the north and the Mediterranean in the south, made the Adriatic safe for navigation. The construction started as early as in the 19th century, when the lighthouses were built along the natural shipping lines. The first one was built and finished on the cape Savudrija in 1818. There is a story connected to its construction, deserving of greatest love dramas. Namely, a respected Austrian politician met a young Croatian girl during a ball on a Vienna court. The amount of the emotions and the affection that took him over took him quickly back to his youth and, having won her over, the unfortunate lover began thinking on how they could spend time together without compromising his social status and marriage. She persuaded him to come to Istria and, upon seeing the cape Savudrija, right away he thought that if he were to build a lighthouse far away from the sights of curious eyes he might come and spend time with his lover undisturbed. Unfortunately, the young lady did not live to see the end of the construction of the lighthouse, because she fell ill and died, and the Savudrija lighthouse was and overture to building dozens of others throughout the Adriatic in the course of the century.
It is hard to say whether the other lighthouses have also been made under the same disguises or building some of their own legends, but one thing that is sure is that due to their dislocation some mystical stories are always tied to lighthouses, making people call them unknown, mysterious, surreal… It is, therefore, not strange that the lighthouse keepers, in those few not automated lighthouses with human crew, are characterized as loners and weirdoes, although we can only be jealous of the life they live, far away from the modern urban ant hills, where our busy rhythm of life does not let us go back to our true roots. They know with how much joy they go back to their lighthouses after just a short staying in the grotto of civilization. And we, how wrong we are in our beliefs, because, really, is there anything prettier than waking up to the sound of the waves and scent of the sea, disturbed only by shrieks of seagulls, and falling asleep on the blue rays of happiness and serenity.

The dislocation contributed also to the lighthouses being rarely visited by the photographers wanting to record them and print just like classical postcards. That is why they seem so exotic in the old postcards. Those in the northern Adriatic are less rare, even though that is not a rule, while in the entire Dalmatia there are just several postcards of the lighthouses, and these are with the motifs of Veli Rat, Palagruža, Mulo near Rogoznica and Pokonji dol near Hvar, although there are far more of them built.
The situation is somewhat improved by the photo-postcards which reveal to us the lighthouse Stončica, as well as some war events like the multiple cannon shooting of the Austrian navy on the beautiful Palagruža in 1915. Thanks to a military photographer from the Austrian torpedo boats, a series of several postcards is a witness of this event today, including the bombing of the island, as well as the final act – the devastation of this monumental edifice. The war propaganda was very active in glorifying successes, so soldiers would often send postcards like this to their families, in order to depict their military war adventures. The Palagruža lighthouse was restored after the World War One finished. A definitely interesting piece of data is the one saying that the demolished lighthouse was known for the strongest light, which could be seen even 26 nautical miles away.
The oldest lighthouse built in Dalmatia back in 1849 is one called Veli Rat on Dugi otok and it has the highest tower among all the lighthouses in the Adriatic. It is known for the fact that as much as 100.000 egg yolks were spent to make its yellow frontage.
Mulo near Rogoznica was first photographed by Ante Vlahović, a dilettante photographer, who used to work as a teacher in Mandalina, and he often came to Rogoznica on weekends, coming to see his uncle, a parson. It was exactly that one, together with some other Vlahović’s photographs, that were published as the first series of Rogoznica postcards in 1899, so Mulo obtained the title of the first Dalmatian lighthouse on a postcard. Today there are only four samples, which are carefully kept in private collections in Rogoznica, Split, Zagreb and Venice. It is the femme fatale, the undreamt dream of numerous collectors.
The photographers mostly took photos of lighthouses so that the monumental towers can be seen, as well as the buildings, so an entirely atypical postcard of the lighthouse in the island of Susak from 1899 is pure joy. It shows the entrance to the building with the inscription PHARUS SANSEGO …, and the family of the lighthouse keeper, excited about the guests arriving, cannot hide smiles on their faces. The entire happening is greeted also by the song of the European goldfinch, coming from the cage hung right by the door, seeming like the birds would like to have a concert in front of the auditorium which was never bigger. This is also a very rare example, witness of the life on the lighthouses in the 19th century.
Each of these few postcards hides a story about itself. They are, definitely, a very important side of the nautical culture of the Croatian Adriatic and they make us think. Today an unnecessary and pointless question is asked – did all those lighthouses, which the Austrian-Hungarian Monarchy built along the Adriatic coast during the 19th century, disturb in fact the natural harmony and peace on all these islets and capes. Now, when the conscience of the ecology is raised, we seem to forget how many ship wrecks have been avoided, and how many lives were saved thanks to these rocky keepers, scattered among 1244 of islands, isles, islets and ridges of the Croatian Adriatic. In front of us there is a new imperative, to nourish and cherish each and every one of them, as the most fragile lace in the chest hiding the dowry of a bride to be, so that their lustre would never fade away. The global glory which was transferred by thousands of tourists who visit them each year will definitely contribute to this. How many special features are hidden in these pearls if someone is ready to fly across the world in order to spend here the most important days of the year, days when one should in a meditative surroundings renew each atom of their energy and regenerate oneself in order to lose the stress. Are WE really aware of the beauty which we are surrounded by?
We are left with nothing but keeping what we inherited, and the being aware of the existence of postcards like this definitely helps here. We, the collectors, will keep searching for them, deeply immersed in the whirls of the most exotic talks, thinking how some day the postcards with motifs of sardines and lobsters would appear in front of us, along with the postcards with the lighthouses on Sušac or Blitvenica, Grujica or Prišnjak. Will our collectors’ dreams come true, and will the fish and the lanterns of the Adriatic survive – time will tell. Let us wish them and us all the luck!
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Ne kažu uzalud da onog trena kada staviš prst u more ostvariš univerzalnu povezanost sa cijelim svijetom.
Istinita je to teza o moru i ljudima koja vrijedi za svih, posebice za one koji more žive i osjećaju ukorijenjeno duboko u sebi. Tako je i s našim morem, blagoslovljenim razvedenom obalom koja mu nabora milo lice, čineći ga time još ljepšim starcem. O njemu bi se moglo mnogo toga izreći i napisati, ali u ovoj knjizi koja priča o razglednicama možemo tek na kraju predstaviti one najposebnije koje povezuju Dalmaciju s ostatkom hrvatskog Jadrana.


Mini poglavlje koje je pred vama predstavlja njegove posebnosti. Brojne stanovnike njegovih faunom bogatih dubina, kao i njegove svjetlonosne vodiče – svjetionike. Dok je serija razglednica jadranskih riba, koju je 1904. napravio lošinjski fotograf Benedikt Lergetporer, apsolutno unikatna i zasigurno spada među najstarije fotografije ovakve tematike, dotle su razglednice s motivima svjetionika izrađivane u komercijalnim nakladama i manje iznenađujuće. Iz današnje perspektive naprosto je nevjerojatna činjenica da je Lergetporer došao na ideju da u suradnji s lokalnim ribarima ovjekovječi njihove svakodnevne ulove i te fotografije upotrijebi kao predloške za izradu foto-razglednica. Vrlo je upitna njihova tiraža i postoji li još neka slična razglednica iz tog opusa. Prikazanih osam razglednica s motivima jadranskih riba pronađene su u Beču gdje su više od 100 godina u albumu bile sastavni dio Lergetporerova opusa od čak 96 razglednica otoka Lošinja, iz razdoblja od 1897. do 1905. Čitav album kupio je 2014., na aukciji u Salzburgu, kolekcionar Franko Neretich koji iz dalekog New Yorka sakuplja strpljivo i nostalgično sve srcu milo, vezano uz rodni otok i Jadran. Otkriće ovih razglednica može se nazvati senzacionalnim jer iz tog vremena, ali i kasnije jednostavno ne postoje neke sličnih motiva. One su više od pukog komada papira, spomenar na sve ribare i njihove neprospavane noći, žuljevite ruke, izmorene od izvlačenja mreža, veslanja i svakodnevne borbe za preživljavanje. Spomenar je to i na bogatstvo jednog od najčistijih mora na svijetu.
Nažalost, ovdje nemamo prigodu vidjeti razglednicu koja prikazuje srdelu – hraniteljicu siromašnih, iako je lošinjski arhipelag u to vrijeme obilovao ovom plavom ribom. Diljem Jadrana početkom 20. stoljeća postojale su mnogobrojne tvornice za preradu srdele koje su zapošljavale na tisuće radnika. Samo u Komiži na otoku Visu bilo ih je šest. Danas prazne, u mjestima koja polako odumiru, sve te tvornice propadaju pod soli i hrđom. Soli onog istog mora koje je nekada davalo, a danas grmi: Eh da, ponizne sluge, sjetit ćete se dana, kada ste bili blagoslovljeni obiljem, a već sada plačete za štetom i nemarom koji prouzročiste svojim nepoštovanjem prema meni!
Kao što je nestala vreva u tvornicama srdela i radnički žar, tako je i ta ista srdela početkom novog milenija nestala na nekoliko godina iz dubina Jadranskog mora, što je poprilično uplašilo sve one koji od mora i s morem žive. Očekivano, pojavilo se pitanje je li to početak kraja… ili ipak nije, već samo podsjetnik na to kako mnogim vrstama prijeti izumiranje. S nostalgijom, prisjetih se priča lastovskih ribara kako se nekada u vrijeme mrijesta jastoga moglo s obale promatrati na desetine njihovih ticala kako vire iz pličina kristalno čistog mora, što se danas smatra tek bujnom maštom. Danas su ovom jedinstvenom raku staništa gotovo uništena, zbog modernih načina lova pa, često, i nekontroliranog izlova. Ali nije jastog jedini ugrožen već i ostali junaci s ovih razglednica: kovač, škampi, trlje… Zar je moguće da je Lergetporer, poput Nostradamusa, predvidio da ćemo jednog dana umjesto odlaska na ribarnicu i uživanja u mediteranskom folkloru koji ona pruža, tek nositi ove ribe u uspomenama pa im je dao glavne uloge u svom kartofiličarskom igrokazu. Vjerujem da ne, motiv je bio isključivo stvaralački, a mi se nadajmo da će ljudska svijest na vrijeme proraditi i dati nam snage suočiti se s izazovima modernog doba i sačuvati mora i njihove faunu.
Stoga, neka glavni akteri ovih osam prikazanih razglednica ne ostanu samo puke uspomene već naša svakodnevica kao, uostalom, i svjetionici koji predstavljaju poseban dodatak vremenu kada se Jadranom plovilo bez suvremenih navigacijskih uređaja, a brodove su vrebale mnoge hridi, golom oku nevidljive.


Svjetlo reflektirano iz ovih kamenih titana spašavalo je živote, otvaralo puteve prema Italiji na sjeveru ili Mediteranu na jugu, učinilo Jadran sigurnim za plovidbu. S izgradnjom se započelo već u 19. stoljeću, kada se svjetionici grade uz prirodne plovne puteve. Prvi se dovršava na rtu Savudrija 1818. Uz njegov nastanak veže se priča dostojna najvećih ljubavnih drama. Naime, ugledni austrijski političar je upoznao mladu Hrvaticu tijekom jednog bala na bečkom dvoru. Količina emocija i simpatija koje su ga obuzele brzo su ga vratile u mladost i, nakon što ju je osvojio, zaljubljeni nesretnik je počeo razmišljati o tome kako bi mogli provoditi vrijeme zajedno, a da ne ugrozi svoj društveni status i brak. Na njen nagovor doputovao je u Istru i, ugledavši rt Savudrija, odmah se dosjetio da bi pod krinkom izgradnje svjetionika izoliranog daleko od pogleda znatiželjnika mogao dolaziti neometano i provoditi vrijeme sa svojom ljubavnicom. Nažalost, mlada dama nije uspjela doživjeti završetak izgradnje svjetionika, naglo se razboljela i umrla.. a savudrijski svjetionik bio je uvertira za izgradnju desetaka drugih širom Jadrana tijekom čitavog stoljeća.
Teško je reći jesu li i drugi nastajali pod sličnim krinkama ili gradeći neke svoje legende, ali je sigurno da se zbog dislociranosti uz svjetionike uvijek vežu neke mistične priče koje ih redovito časte atributima nepoznati, tajanstveni, nestvarni…. Stoga, nije ni čudno što se svjetioničari, na ono malo svjetionika koji nisu postali automatizirani pa i danas imaju ljudsku posadu, karakteriziraju kao samotnjaci i čudaci, iako samo možemo biti ljubomorni na život koji one vode, daleko od modernih gradskih mravinjaka, gdje nam užurbani ritam življenja ne dozvoljava vratiti se istinskim korijenima. Znaju oni s kolikim veseljem se vraćaju na svjetionik nakon kratkotrajnog boravka u grotlu civilizacije. A mi, kako li tek griješimo u svojim uvjerenjima jer, uistinu, postoji li nešto ljepše od onog kada se budiš uz šum valova i miris mora remećen tek ponekim krikom galebova, a toneš u san na modrim zrakama sreće i spokoja?
Dislociranost je i doprinijela tome da su svjetionike rijetko posjećivali fotografi u želji da ih snime i tiskaju kao klasične razglednice.Stoga danas i djeluju tako egzotično na starim razglednicama. Oni na sjevernom Jadranu manje su rijetki, iako ni to nije pravilo, dok je u čitavoj Dalmaciji poznato tek nekoliko razglednica svjetionika i to s motivima Velog Rata, Palagruže, Mula kod Rogoznice i Pokonjeg dola kod Hvara, iako ih je izgrađeno daleko više.
Situaciju donekle popravljaju foto-razglednice koje nam otkrivaju neke ratne događaje poput višekratne kanonade austrijske mornarice po ljepotici Palagruži 1915. Zahvaljujući vojnom fotografu s austrijskih torpednih brodova, danas o ovom događaju svjedoči serija od nekoliko razglednica, koje uključuju bombardiranje otoka, kao i završni čin – ruševine ovog monumentalnog zdanja. Ratna propaganda bila je vrlo aktivna u veličanju uspjeha, pa su ovakve razglednice često slali vojnici svojim obiteljima, kako bi im dočarali svoje vojničke ratne avanture. Svjetionik Palagruža obnovljen je po završetku Prvog svjetskog rata. Svakako, zanimljiv je i podatak da je srušeni svjetionik bio poznat po najsnažnijem svjetlu, koje je bilo vidljivo na čak 26 nautičkih milja. Najstariji svjetionik izgrađen u Dalmaciji daleke 1849. je Veli Rat na Dugom otoku i ima najviši toranj među svim jadranskim svjetionicima. Poznat je po tome da je za izradu njegovog pročelja potrošeno čak 100 000 žumanjaka. Mulo kod Rogoznice prvi je 1898. fotografirao Ante Vlahović, šibenski fotoamater, koji je Rogoznicu često pohodio vikendom dolazeći u posjet svom ujaku župniku. Upravo ta, i još nekoliko, fotografija Vlahovića objavljene su kao prva serija razglednica Rogoznice 1899. pa je Mulo ponio titulu prvog dalmatinskog svjetionika na razglednici. Danas se zna za samo četiri sačuvana primjerka pomno čuvana u privatnim zbirkama u Rogoznici, Splitu, Zagrebu i Veneciji. Ona je femme fatale, nedosanjani san mnogih sakupljača.
Fotografi su svjetionike najčešće snimali tako da se vide monumentalni tornjevi i zgrade, stoga posebno raduje sasvim atipična razglednica svjetionika na otoku Susku iz 1899. Prikazuje ulaz u samu zgradu s natpisom PHARUS SANSEGO …, a svjetioničarska obitelj, uzbuđena zbog dolaska gostiju, ne može sakriti osmijeh sa svojih lica. Čitavu zgodu pozdravlja i pjev grdelina iz krletki obješenih pokraj vrata kojim kao da žele održati koncert pred nikad većim auditorijem. U pitanju je i vrlo rijedak primjer koji svjedoči o životu na svjetionicima u 19. stoljeću.
Svaka od ovih malobrojnih razglednica krije neku priču o sebi. One su, svakako, važan prilog pomorskoj kulturi hrvatskog Jadrana i navode na razmišljanje. Danas se postavlja bespotrebno i bespredmetno pitanje jesu li svi ti svjetionici koje je gradila Austro-Ugarska Monarhija diljem jadranske obale tijekom 19. stoljeća narušili prirodnu harmoniju i mir na svim tim hridinama i rtovima. Sada, kada se podiže ekološka svijest, kao da se zaboravlja koliko brodoloma je izbjegnuto, a života spašeno zahvaljujući ovim kamenim čuvarima, razasutim između 1244 otoka, otočića, hridi i grebena hrvatskog Jadrana. Pred nama je imperativ da svakog od njih, kao najkrhkiju čipku u škrinji dotarice, njegujemo i čuvamo, kako njihov sjaj nikad ne bi izblijedio. Globalna slava koju o njima prenose tisuće turista koji ih svaku godinu pohode svakako će u tome doprinijeti. Koliko li samo posebnosti kriju ovi biseri kada je netko spreman preletjeti pola svijeta da bi tu proveo najvažnije dane u godini, dane kada u meditativnom okruženju treba obnoviti svaki atom svoje energije i regenerirati se od nakupljenog stresa. Jesmo li MI uistinu svjesni ljepote kojom smo okruženi?


Preostaje nam samo čuvati ono što smo naslijedili, u čemu, svakako, pomaže i svijest o postojanju ovakvih razglednica. Mi kolekcionari, i dalje ćemo tragati za njima, duboko zadubljeni u vrtloge najegzotičnijih razgovora, zamišljajući kako nam se jednog dana ukazuju i razglednice s motivima srdela i jastoga, svjetionika na Sušcu ili Blitvenici, Grujici ili Prišnjaku? Hoće li se sakupljački snovi ostvariti, a ribe i lanterne Jadrana opstati – vrijeme će pokazati. Poželimo i njima i nama sreću!

Igor Goleš
